pullRequest.title: Mqtt proxy IPC integration
pullRequest.bodyText:
Issue #, if available:
Description of changes:
MQTT Proxy IPC integration
Why is this change necessary:
How was this change tested:
Unit tests in MqttProxyIPCAgentTest
Integ test in IPCMqttProxyTest
Any additional information or context required to review the change:
Checklist:

 Updated the README if applicable
 Updated or added new unit tests
 Updated or added new integration tests
 Updated or added new end-to-end tests

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

nodes.bodyText:
Recommendation generated by Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer. Leave feedback on this recommendation by replying to the comment or by reacting to the comment using emoji.
Problem
You are using a ConcurrentHashMap, but your usage of containsKey() and get() may not be thread-safe at lines: 118 and 140. In between the check and the get() another thread can remove the key and the get() will return null. The remove that can remove the key is at line: 204.
Fix
Consider calling get(), checking instead of your current check if the returned object is null, and then using that object only, without calling get() again.
More info
View an example on GitHub (external link).

Ditch the if statements, just call the builder method directly, regardless of value

I don't think we can wait for the future to complete. If the network is doing it's going to limit throughput to 2 TPS.
I'll likely add a new API that returns whether or not the message was successfully queued, and that can be used to construct an appropriate response (success if queued, else failure)
Are these response objects empty? If they are then we need to change that...
I'm assuming this still needs some work. How do you plan to route this to the correct subscriber? Also, we can't wait on any futures here. It will block the mqtt client thread
Need qos(request.getQos())

I took another look at the model, and it looks like errors are modeled separately. What you have here looks good - though I think we could probably pull the error out of the exception instead of hardcoding a generic error. It's helpful for the customer to know it failed because the spool is full
What's the scope of this object? Per client or per request? I'm assuming the former, in which case, what happens if the client makes multiple calls to subscribe to multiple topics?
e2e tests are slow, not sure I'd recommend a e2e test. Integ is sufficient given the other coverage that mqtt has.
log error
You never remove the subscription. If someone unsubscribe, they need to be removed from this map
log exception and return an error to the customer
this is unsubscribing, what do you need these fields for?
Is calling both required?
Add license header

nodes.bodyText: Does this throw a meaningful error?

commit.message: Updating the server framework library code and smithy generated code
Adding unit tests for IPCService, LifecycleService and LifecycleAgent
Adding event stream agent for CLI and unit tests for CLi event stream agent
Updated to latest code for server library and smithy generated code
Removing the IPC socket descriptor file in IPC startup
Updating integ tests to use the new IPC lifecycle APIs
Updating the server and client code for ipc library
Adding connect message suppliers and using them for IPC connect
Updating the event stream rpc server, client and model to latest. Also updating the Greengrass IPC model to latest generated code
Updating ipc server and client code with latest exception handling fixes to both
Changing the name of the socket path env variable
Excluding ipc sdk code from unit test coverage
Changing the version of CRT repo to pull the latest CRT jar
Updated to generated code from latest smithy model
Making post event and pre component event calls synchronous

nodes.bodyText: log

remove lifecycle.
Just do ServiceName: {}

nodes.bodyText: Why are you calling getNow that doesn't give it any time to complete the future.
This is not correct. You need to pull the message out of the exception (e.getCause().getMessage()). This should also get logged with the cause.
do we have any logging for failed auth attempts?
But they have no idea why it failed. We should be helpful to the customer.
Would it make sense to just unsubscribe when the subscription stream has ended? Not sure we actually need a separate event. @abanthiy

commit.message: Adding comments to clarify IpcServer parameters for domain sockets
Making subscribeToComponent synchronous in DeploymentConfigMerging and DeploymentTaskIntegration test

nodes.bodyText: don't log the message and the cause. Just call log()

commit.message: remove Unsubscribe handler from Mqtt Proxy

nodes.bodyText: This doesn't make sense. You're formatting e and e.getMessage() only use e.getMessage()
same as below
Same
Same

As discussed offline, this is going to need to change. Need to sign off with Jamie, but current thinking is that we need a separate stream for message delivery events so that we can scalably receive publish requests while offline (i.e. we can't pile up streams, threads, objects, etc -- the spool itself should be the limiting factor).
We can address this separately.
Can be backed out after we make the publish changes
Is closeStream() async? Sleeping problem isn't the most robust way to handle this
